docs.lead_paragraph: On the White House's official blog, Nancy-Ann DeParle, the director of the Office of Health Reform, rebuts recent claims by the insurance industry that the proposed health care overhaul would actually increase the cost of premiums.

headline.main: Obama Official and Goldman Assess Insurers

docs.abstract: The White House's health care chief and Goldman Sachs agree that the health care legislation could hit insurers' profits hard.
docs.snippet: The White House's health care chief and Goldman Sachs agree that the health care legislation could hit insurers' profits hard.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Michelle Obama pitched the president's health care reform efforts to a room of women at the White House last week, one group of New Yorkers present clung to every word.

headline.main: Help for Gay Caregivers Who Look After Elderly

docs.abstract: Services and Advocacy for GLBT Elders (SAGE) began a program to help gay and lesbian caregivers who tend to the elderly.

docs.lead_paragraph: Critics say the industry is trying to establish a higher price base before Congress passes legislation that tries to curb drug spending in coming years.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study shows that electronic health records have so far not improved health care quality or cost. The reason may be that the technology is not being fully exploited.

docs.lead_paragraph: Regarding Nicholas Kristof's column, "America's defining choice" (Views, Nov. 13): What President Obama decides to do with Afghanistan, and what the U.S. Congress finally decides to do about health care reform, will truly define America for decades to come.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, hopes to finalize the Senate version of major health care legislation this week. But don't count the days. Mr. Reid and his aides have been saying the same thing for a month, ever since the Senate Finance Committee approved its bill on Oct. 13.

headline.main: Senate's Counting And Recounting Add Up to Delay
headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Senate majority leader Harry Reid has repeatedly gone back to Congressional Budget Office with variations of his version of health care reform legislation, trying to figure out how to limit overall cost while increasing number of people who would gain coverage; must choose between following recommendation of experts on health economics and angering crucial Democratic constituency; in meantime, frustration is growing among some lawmakers over delay of bill they have not yet seen; photos (M)
